speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: SCENE IV. LANGLEY. The DUKE OF YORK's garden.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter the QUEEN and two Ladies

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: What sport shall we devise here in this garden,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: To drive away the heavy thought of care?

speaker: Lady
text_entry: Madam, we'll play at bowls.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: 'Twill make me think the world is full of rubs,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And that my fortune rubs against the bias.

speaker: Lady
text_entry: Madam, we'll dance.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: My legs can keep no measure in delight,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: When my poor heart no measure keeps in grief:

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Therefore, no dancing, girl; some other sport.

speaker: Lady
text_entry: Madam, we'll tell tales.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Of sorrow or of joy?

speaker: Lady
text_entry: Of either, madam.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Of neither, girl:

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: For of joy, being altogether wanting,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: It doth remember me the more of sorrow;

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Or if of grief, being altogether had,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: It adds more sorrow to my want of joy:

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: For what I have I need not to repeat;

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And what I want it boots not to complain.

speaker: Lady
text_entry: Madam, I'll sing.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: 'Tis well that thou hast cause

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: But thou shouldst please me better, wouldst thou weep.

speaker: Lady
text_entry: I could weep, madam, would it do you good.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And I could sing, would weeping do me good,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And never borrow any tear of thee.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Enter a Gardener, and two Servants

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: But stay, here come the gardeners:

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Let's step into the shadow of these trees.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: My wretchedness unto a row of pins,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: They'll talk of state; for every one doth so

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Against a change; woe is forerun with woe.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: QUEEN and Ladies retire

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Go, bind thou up yon dangling apricocks,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Which, like unruly children, make their sire

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Stoop with oppression of their prodigal weight:

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Give some supportance to the bending twigs.

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Go thou, and like an executioner,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Cut off the heads of too fast growing sprays,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: That look too lofty in our commonwealth:

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: All must be even in our government.

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: You thus employ'd, I will go root away

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: The noisome weeds, which without profit suck

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: The soil's fertility from wholesome flowers.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Why should we in the compass of a pale

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Keep law and form and due proportion,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Showing, as in a model, our firm estate,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: When our sea-walled garden, the whole land,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Is full of weeds, her fairest flowers choked up,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Her fruit-trees all upturned, her hedges ruin'd,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Her knots disorder'd and her wholesome herbs

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Swarming with caterpillars?

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Hold thy peace:

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: He that hath suffer'd this disorder'd spring

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Hath now himself met with the fall of leaf:

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: The weeds which his broad-spreading leaves did shelter,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: That seem'd in eating him to hold him up,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Are pluck'd up root and all by Bolingbroke,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: I mean the Earl of Wiltshire, Bushy, Green.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: What, are they dead?

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: They are; and Bolingbroke

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Hath seized the wasteful king. O, what pity is it

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: That he had not so trimm'd and dress'd his land

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: As we this garden! We at time of year

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Do wound the bark, the skin of our fruit-trees,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Lest, being over-proud in sap and blood,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: With too much riches it confound itself:

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Had he done so to great and growing men,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: They might have lived to bear and he to taste

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Their fruits of duty: superfluous branches

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: We lop away, that bearing boughs may live:

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Had he done so, himself had borne the crown,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Which waste of idle hours hath quite thrown down.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: What, think you then the king shall be deposed?

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Depress'd he is already, and deposed

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: 'Tis doubt he will be: letters came last night

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: To a dear friend of the good Duke of York's,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: That tell black tidings.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: O, I am press'd to death through want of speaking!

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Coming forward

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Thou, old Adam's likeness, set to dress this garden,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: How dares thy harsh rude tongue sound this unpleasing news?

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: What Eve, what serpent, hath suggested thee

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: To make a second fall of cursed man?

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Why dost thou say King Richard is deposed?

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Darest thou, thou little better thing than earth,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Divine his downfall? Say, where, when, and how,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Camest thou by this ill tidings? speak, thou wretch.

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Pardon me, madam: little joy have I

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: To breathe this news; yet what I say is true.

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: King Richard, he is in the mighty hold

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Of Bolingbroke: their fortunes both are weigh'd:

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: In your lord's scale is nothing but himself,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: And some few vanities that make him light;

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: But in the balance of great Bolingbroke,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Besides himself, are all the English peers,

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: And with that odds he weighs King Richard down.

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: Post you to London, and you will find it so;

speaker: Gardener
text_entry: I speak no more than every one doth know.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Nimble mischance, that art so light of foot,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Doth not thy embassage belong to me,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: And am I last that knows it? O, thou think'st

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: To serve me last, that I may longest keep

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Thy sorrow in my breast. Come, ladies, go,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: To meet at London London's king in woe.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: What, was I born to this, that my sad look

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Should grace the triumph of great Bolingbroke?

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Gardener, for telling me these news of woe,

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Pray God the plants thou graft'st may never grow.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: Exeunt QUEEN and Ladies

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: Poor queen! so that thy state might be no worse,

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: I would my skill were subject to thy curse.

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: Here did she fall a tear; here in this place

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: I'll set a bank of rue, sour herb of grace:

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: Rue, even for ruth, here shortly shall be seen,

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: In the remembrance of a weeping queen.

speaker: GARDENER
text_entry: Exeunt
